facts: A mouse's heart beats 632 times per minute, over 10 times faster than a human heart.
Mice can squeeze through openings as small as a dime due to their flexible skeletal structure.
Mice are excellent jumpers, capable of leaping up to 12 inches high from a standing position.
A mouse's teeth grow continuously throughout its life, requiring constant gnawing to keep them short.
Mice communicate using ultrasonic vocalizations that are inaudible to humans.
A female mouse can have 5-10 litters per year, with each litter containing 3-14 pups.
Mice are highly social animals and will become lonely or depressed without companionship.
A mouse's whiskers are highly sensitive and help them navigate in complete darkness.
Mice are excellent swimmers and can tread water for up to three days.
The lifespan of a wild mouse is typically 5-6 months, while pet mice can live 1-3 years.
Mice are omnivores but prefer grains, seeds, and fruits when available.
A mouse can travel up to 8 miles per hour when running at full speed.
Mice are color blind and see the world primarily in shades of gray.
The house mouse originated in Central Asia and has spread worldwide alongside humans.
Mice use their tails for balance when climbing and navigating narrow spaces.
A mouse's gestation period is only 19-21 days, one of the shortest among mammals.
Mice are highly intelligent and can learn to navigate complex mazes.
The largest mouse species, the African giant pouched rat, can weigh up to 3 pounds.
Mice are neophobic, meaning they fear new objects and changes in their environment.
Laboratory mice have contributed to numerous medical breakthroughs and genetic discoveries.
